Sorry that I don't speak Spanish, but I'm only visiting Buenos Aires from New York.  This is my third visit to Buenos Aires, and every time I've been here I've always noticed the same thing: Argentina has wonderful food, but does Italian food very poorly. 
This coming form someone who spent 6 months in Italy, is the son of Italian immigrants and knows and loves Italian food.
However, Bella Italia knows Italian food pretty well. The pasta dishes were actually "pastasciute", that is dry pasta dishes the way they are supposed to be.  
We had salads to start--hojas verdes and the brie cheese salad.  The former was great and refreshing, the second one a little overwhelmed with a honey dressing.  We had the spaghetti verdi con verduras y langostinas, which was delightful in a fresh tomato sauce, rare for Buenos Aires' common salsa fileto.  We also had the tagliolini with mushrooms, leeks and basil, also wonderful, and reminiscent of pasta dishes I had in Italy.
Finally, get the tiramisu.  One of the best I've had (in all my travels), period!
Overall, highly recommended, but I did notice that the prices are quite high for BA, particularly the wine, a Norton Sauvignon Blanc at $36 pesos.
